item.title:
Imagine a future in which your daily interaction with the world of information is mediated by an AI assistant.
This AI assistant would be like an active repository of all human knowledge.
It will become your best rampart *against* misinformation.

item.title: A commonly heard statement in discussions of mind/body problem and embodied cognition is "people think, not brains" or "people act, not brains". Here's why I think this is an intuitively appealing, but unhelpful idea.
item.description: A commonly heard statement in discussions of mind/body problem and embodied cognition is "people think, not brains" or "people act, not brains". Here's why I think this is an intuitively appealing, but unhelpful idea.
item.content:encoded: A commonly heard statement in discussions of mind/body problem and embodied cognition is "people think, not brains" or "people act, not brains". Here's why I think this is an intuitively appealing, but unhelpful idea.

item.title: Consider your smartphone. Imagine that someone took out all the electronics, leaving just an empty shell and dead screen. Now, which of these - electronics or shell - is "a phone"? I think most people would say neither.
item.description: Consider your smartphone. Imagine that someone took out all the electronics, leaving just an empty shell and dead screen. Now, which of these - electronics or shell - is "a phone"? I think most people would say neither.
item.content:encoded: Consider your smartphone. Imagine that someone took out all the electronics, leaving just an empty shell and dead screen. Now, which of these - electronics or shell - is "a phone"? I think most people would say neither.

item.title: My intuition is that neither the electronics of a phone nor the shell are "a phone" - they are only "a phone" when together. This is just the same intuition as saying that a brain is not a person, neither is a brainless body, but only when together.
item.description: My intuition is that neither the electronics of a phone nor the shell are "a phone" - they are only "a phone" when together. This is just the same intuition as saying that a brain is not a person, neither is a brainless body, but only when together.

item.title:
On one of my first papers, it took three months to get those initial reviews. I remember wondering at the time why it could possibly take so long.
And then I worked as an editor for a while, and learned why, and how much it depends on us, the reviewers.
A long thread: https://t.co/Fp8sQHz7TE
item.description:
On one of my first papers, it took three months to get those initial reviews. I remember wondering at the time why it could possibly take so long.
And then I worked as an editor for a while, and learned why, and how much it depends on us, the reviewers.
A long thread: https://t.co/Fp8sQHz7TE
item.content:encoded: On one of my first papers, it took three months to get those initial reviews. I remember wondering at the time why it could possibly take so long. And then I worked as an editor for a while, and learned why, and how much it depends on us, the reviewers. A long thread: https://t.co/Fp8sQHz7TE

item.title:
Suppose a manuscript is submitted. It will go through some Q&A to make sure it's complete, and then someone has to assign it to a handling editor.
They have other manuscripts to read, so by the time they get to your manuscript, we're well over a week in.
item.description:
Suppose a manuscript is submitted. It will go through some Q&A to make sure it's complete, and then someone has to assign it to a handling editor.
They have other manuscripts to read, so by the time they get to your manuscript, we're well over a week in.
item.content:encoded: Suppose a manuscript is submitted. It will go through some Q&A to make sure it's complete, and then someone has to assign it to a handling editor. They have other manuscripts to read, so by the time they get to your manuscript, we're well over a week in.

item.title: Suppose the editor likes it, they might want to consult with other editors before inviting reviewers, and those reviewers usually don't respond immediately. Once all reviewers have agreed, two weeks have passed.
item.description: Suppose the editor likes it, they might want to consult with other editors before inviting reviewers, and those reviewers usually don't respond immediately. Once all reviewers have agreed, two weeks have passed.
item.content:encoded: Suppose the editor likes it, they might want to consult with other editors before inviting reviewers, and those reviewers usually don't respond immediately. Once all reviewers have agreed, two weeks have passed.

item.title:
In an ideal situation, those reviews are submitted in two weeks, evaluated within a few days, and you have a decision in a little over a month.
But what if one of the reviewers does not submit their review?
item.description:
In an ideal situation, those reviews are submitted in two weeks, evaluated within a few days, and you have a decision in a little over a month.
But what if one of the reviewers does not submit their review?
item.content:encoded: In an ideal situation, those reviews are submitted in two weeks, evaluated within a few days, and you have a decision in a little over a month. But what if one of the reviewers does not submit their review?

item.title:
The editor doesn't want to immediately drop that reviewer: maybe they were still working on it, maybe something last-minute popped up. Whatever the case may be, reviewers are busy and reviews are a low priority.
So, a few reminders are send, and the editor waits.
item.description:
The editor doesn't want to immediately drop that reviewer: maybe they were still working on it, maybe something last-minute popped up. Whatever the case may be, reviewers are busy and reviews are a low priority.
So, a few reminders are send, and the editor waits.
item.content:encoded: The editor doesn't want to immediately drop that reviewer: maybe they were still working on it, maybe something last-minute popped up. Whatever the case may be, reviewers are busy and reviews are a low priority. So, a few reminders are send, and the editor waits.

item.title:
Suppose the reviewer still does not respond. Now we're five weeks in, and the editor sends a final reminder. They give it a few more days, just in case the reviewer was going to respond after all (it happens).
In the meantime, the editor starts inviting other reviewers.
item.description:
Suppose the reviewer still does not respond. Now we're five weeks in, and the editor sends a final reminder. They give it a few more days, just in case the reviewer was going to respond after all (it happens).
In the meantime, the editor starts inviting other reviewers.
item.content:encoded: Suppose the reviewer still does not respond. Now we're five weeks in, and the editor sends a final reminder. They give it a few more days, just in case the reviewer was going to respond after all (it happens). In the meantime, the editor starts inviting other reviewers.

item.title:
Invitations are send out, but get no response. The editor again waits a few days for potential reviewers to respond, before inviting others.
Go through two rounds of this, and you're looking at seven weeks. At long last, a reviewer accepts! They're given two weeks to review.
item.description:
Invitations are send out, but get no response. The editor again waits a few days for potential reviewers to respond, before inviting others.
Go through two rounds of this, and you're looking at seven weeks. At long last, a reviewer accepts! They're given two weeks to review.
item.content:encoded: Invitations are send out, but get no response. The editor again waits a few days for potential reviewers to respond, before inviting others. Go through two rounds of this, and you're looking at seven weeks. At long last, a reviewer accepts! They're given two weeks to review.

item.title:
Now at nine weeks, the reviewer sends an email: something came up, and they need another two weeks before they can complete their review.
What do you do? Inviting yet another reviewer will also take at least two weeks, maybe more. So the editor agrees to extend the deadline.
item.description:
Now at nine weeks, the reviewer sends an email: something came up, and they need another two weeks before they can complete their review.
What do you do? Inviting yet another reviewer will also take at least two weeks, maybe more. So the editor agrees to extend the deadline.
item.content:encoded: Now at nine weeks, the reviewer sends an email: something came up, and they need another two weeks before they can complete their review. What do you do? Inviting yet another reviewer will also take at least two weeks, maybe more. So the editor agrees to extend the deadline.

item.title:
True to their word, the reviewer submits their review on time! It takes a few days to go over their review and consult with other editors, but finally, a decision is send to the author.
But it took almost three months to get here.
item.description:
True to their word, the reviewer submits their review on time! It takes a few days to go over their review and consult with other editors, but finally, a decision is send to the author.
But it took almost three months to get here.
item.content:encoded: True to their word, the reviewer submits their review on time! It takes a few days to go over their review and consult with other editors, but finally, a decision is send to the author. But it took almost three months to get here.

item.title:
Could this have been done faster? Maybe. If you immediately drop a reviewer when they go past the deadline, you might save a week. But what if that reviewer was going to send their review the next day?
By dropping them, you would have actually lost over two weeks.
item.description:
Could this have been done faster? Maybe. If you immediately drop a reviewer when they go past the deadline, you might save a week. But what if that reviewer was going to send their review the next day?
By dropping them, you would have actually lost over two weeks.
item.content:encoded: Could this have been done faster? Maybe. If you immediately drop a reviewer when they go past the deadline, you might save a week. But what if that reviewer was going to send their review the next day? By dropping them, you would have actually lost over two weeks.

item.title: Could the editor have denied the extension? Yes, but again, inviting a new reviewer would also have taken at least two weeks. There was no scenario where the editor could guarantee a faster review.
item.description: Could the editor have denied the extension? Yes, but again, inviting a new reviewer would also have taken at least two weeks. There was no scenario where the editor could guarantee a faster review.
item.content:encoded: Could the editor have denied the extension? Yes, but again, inviting a new reviewer would also have taken at least two weeks. There was no scenario where the editor could guarantee a faster review.

item.title:
Realistically, the only way an editor could speed this up, is by not replacing a reviewer who dropped out. I sometimes did this, when the other reviewers covered a manuscript well enough, or if it was clear the manuscript should be rejected.
A long review process is a good sign!
item.description:
Realistically, the only way an editor could speed this up, is by not replacing a reviewer who dropped out. I sometimes did this, when the other reviewers covered a manuscript well enough, or if it was clear the manuscript should be rejected.
A long review process is a good sign!
item.content:encoded: Realistically, the only way an editor could speed this up, is by not replacing a reviewer who dropped out. I sometimes did this, when the other reviewers covered a manuscript well enough, or if it was clear the manuscript should be rejected. A long review process is a good sign!

item.title:
Now imagine if the reviewer who dropped out had send a single, one-line email after a week: "sorry, I can't review after all".
That single message would have sped up the process by about three weeks. More, if the editor was very busy or the timing coincided with a holiday.
item.description:
Now imagine if the reviewer who dropped out had send a single, one-line email after a week: "sorry, I can't review after all".
That single message would have sped up the process by about three weeks. More, if the editor was very busy or the timing coincided with a holiday.
item.content:encoded: Now imagine if the reviewer who dropped out had send a single, one-line email after a week: "sorry, I can't review after all". That single message would have sped up the process by about three weeks. More, if the editor was very busy or the timing coincided with a holiday.

item.title:
This isn't meant to blame and shame, merely to illustrate how much a manuscript can be delayed by a single reviewer not responding. How even hitting that "decline to review" button helps to speed up the process.
How an editor can do everything right, and still take months.
item.description:
This isn't meant to blame and shame, merely to illustrate how much a manuscript can be delayed by a single reviewer not responding. How even hitting that "decline to review" button helps to speed up the process.
How an editor can do everything right, and still take months.
item.content:encoded: This isn't meant to blame and shame, merely to illustrate how much a manuscript can be delayed by a single reviewer not responding. How even hitting that "decline to review" button helps to speed up the process. How an editor can do everything right, and still take months.

item.title:
Mind you, sometimes a delay really is just due to an editor forgetting to look at your manuscript. It has happened to me, and in such cases, it helps if authors enquire about their manuscript.
Don't hesitate to e-mail your editor if it has taken more than a month or two!
item.description:
Mind you, sometimes a delay really is just due to an editor forgetting to look at your manuscript. It has happened to me, and in such cases, it helps if authors enquire about their manuscript.
Don't hesitate to e-mail your editor if it has taken more than a month or two!
item.content:encoded: Mind you, sometimes a delay really is just due to an editor forgetting to look at your manuscript. It has happened to me, and in such cases, it helps if authors enquire about their manuscript. Don't hesitate to e-mail your editor if it has taken more than a month or two!

item.title:
Stane Street is the modern name of the 91 km-long Roman road in southern England that linked Londinium (London) to Noviomagus Reginorum (Chichester). This is view southwestwards along Mill Lane to the northeast of Halnaker
[source, photo by Rob Farrow: https://t.co/jbL6K1UhGc] https://t.co/GMSDfvITsP
